webwork-tex.statement:
The table below gives values of an invertible function \(f(x)\): \leavevmode\\\relax
\par\smallskip\begin{center}\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
\(x\) &\ -2\ &\ -1\ &\ 0\ &\ 1\ &\ 2\ \\ \hline
\(f(x)\) &\ -3\ &\ 0\ &\ 2\ &\ 5\ &\ 4\ \\ \hline
\end {tabular}\end{center}\par\smallskip
\leavevmode\\\relax (a) \(f(0) =\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{5ex}{\hrulefill}} \par (b) \(f(\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{5ex}{\hrulefill}} \() = 0\) \par (c) \(f^{-1}(0) =\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{5ex}{\hrulefill}} \par (d) \(f^{-1}(\) \mbox{\parbox[t]{5ex}{\hrulefill}} \() = 0\)
\par \par {\bf Solution: }\par {\bf SOLUTION } \par To find values of \(f(x)\), read the table from top to bottom, so \(f(0)= 2\) and \(f(-1)=0\). \par To find values of \(f^{-1}\), read the table in the opposite direction (from bottom to top), so \(f^{-1}(0)= -1\) and \(f^{-1}(2)=0\). \par Since the values (0,2) are paired in the table, we know \(f(0)=2\) and \(f^{-1}(2)=0\). Thus, knowing the answer to (a) tells us the answer to (d). Similarly, the answer to (b) tells us that the values \((-1,0)\) are paired in the table, so \(f^{-1}(0)= -1\) too.
\par
